words.meaning: Hostile and aggressive.
examples: He was drunk and belligerent.
The belligerent man was escorted out of the bar by the bouncer.

words.meaning: To express discontent or sorrow over (something).
examples: He bemoaned the fact that he was too old to play sports.
She bemoaned the loss of her favorite necklace.

words.meaning: The quality or state of being good, kind, or charitable.
examples: The hospital was founded on the beneficence of a wealthy philanthropist.
His beneficence was well known throughout the community.

words.meaning: (of a person) generous or doing good.
examples: A beneficent ruler is loved by his people.
The beneficent organization provides food and shelter for the homeless.

words.meaning: Well meaning and kindly.
examples: A benevolent smile lit up her face.
The benevolent millionaire donated to numerous charities.

words.meaning: In a state of pitiful or contemptible intellectual or moral ignorance.
examples: They are trying to help the benighted people of the region.
His benighted views on science were shocking.

words.meaning: Gentle and kindly; not harmful in effect.
examples: The tumor was found to be benign.
He has a benign and friendly personality.

words.meaning: A natural talent or inclination.
examples: She has a bent for music.
He has a scientific bent.

words.meaning: To scold or criticize (someone) angrily.
examples: The coach berated the team for their poor performance.
She berated her son for being late.

words.meaning: Deprived of or lacking something, especially a nonmaterial asset.
examples: He was bereft of hope after losing his job.
The room was bereft of any decoration.

words.meaning: To ask (someone) urgently and fervently to do something; implore.
examples: I beseech you to tell the truth.
She beseeched him to stay.

words.meaning: To surround (a place) with armed forces in order to capture it or force its surrender.
examples: The army besieged the city for months.
He was besieged by reporters asking for an interview.

words.meaning: To damage the reputation of (someone or something) in the opinion of others.
examples: He had besmirched the family name.
The scandal besmirched his reputation.

words.meaning: Strongly infatuated.
examples: He was completely besotted with her.
The besotted couple couldn't keep their hands off each other.

words.meaning: To be unfaithful in guarding, maintaining, or fulfilling; to be disloyal to.
examples: He betrayed his country by selling secrets to the enemy.
Her trembling hands betrayed her nervousness.

words.meaning: A large group of people or things of a particular kind.
examples: A bevy of beauties greeted the guests.
He was surrounded by a bevy of admirers.

words.meaning: Prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another, usually in a way considered to be unfair.
examples: The news report showed a clear bias towards the government.
The company was accused of bias in its hiring practices.

words.meaning: Unfairly prejudiced for or against someone or something.
examples: The referee was clearly biased towards the home team.
The article was heavily biased and one-sided.

words.meaning: To divide into two branches or forks.
examples: The river bifurcates into two smaller streams.
The road bifurcates at the next intersection.

words.meaning: Divided into two branches or forks.
examples: The path bifurcated, and he didn't know which way to go.
The company's management structure is bifurcated.

words.meaning: A person who is intolerant toward those holding different opinions.
examples: He was a religious bigot who refused to tolerate other faiths.
The politician was accused of being a racist bigot.

words.meaning: Nonsense; rubbish.
examples: Don't talk such bilge!
His speech was full of pretentious bilge.

words.meaning: Spiteful; bad-tempered.
examples: He was a bilious old man who complained about everything.
She had a bilious look on her face.

words.meaning: To obtain or withhold money from (someone) by deceit or without justification; cheat or defraud.
examples: He bilked his investors out of millions of dollars.
The con artist bilked the elderly couple out of their life savings.

words.meaning: An unpleasant or difficult fact or situation that is hard to accept.
examples: Losing the championship was a bitter pill to swallow.
It was a bitter pill to swallow when he was laid off from his job.

words.meaning: Very strange or unusual.
examples: He had a bizarre sense of humor.
The bizarre story was hard to believe.

words.meaning: Unimpressed or indifferent to something because one has experienced or seen it so often before.
examples: He was blase about the celebrity sightings.
She had a blase attitude towards the fancy party.

words.meaning: Unimpressed or indifferent to something because one has experienced or seen it so often before.
examples: After years of traveling, he had a blasé attitude towards new places.
The movie star was blasé about all the attention he received.

words.meaning: (of bad behavior) done openly and unashamedly.
examples: It was a blatant lie.
The blatant disregard for the rules was shocking.

words.meaning: (of a situation or future prospect) not hopeful or encouraging; depressing.
examples: The future looks bleak for the company.
The economic outlook is bleak.

words.meaning: A thing that spoils or damages something.
examples: The abandoned factory is a blight on the neighborhood.
Urban blight is a major problem in many cities.

words.meaning: Having or showing a limited outlook.
examples: He has a blinkered view of the world.
The blinkered approach to the problem will not solve it.

words.meaning: Perfect happiness; great joy.
examples: The couple was in a state of pure bliss after their wedding.
Lying on the beach was sheer bliss.

words.meaning: Showing a casual and cheerful indifference considered to be callous or improper.
examples: He had a blithe disregard for the feelings of others.
The blithe spirit of the young girl was contagious.

words.meaning: To alternate between two moods, opinions, or courses of action.
examples: He keeps blowing hot and cold about the trip.
The government has been blowing hot and cold on this issue.

words.meaning: To beat (someone) repeatedly with a bludgeon or other heavy object.
examples: He was bludgeoned to death.
The lawyer bludgeoned the witness with questions.

words.meaning: Denoting companies or their shares considered to be a reliable investment, though less secure than gilt-edged stock.
examples: He invested his money in blue chip stocks.
The company is a blue chip in the tech industry.

words.meaning: A stupid or careless mistake.
examples: He made a terrible blunder that cost him the game.
The company made a major blunder in its marketing campaign.

words.meaning: (of a person or remark) uncompromisingly forthright.
examples: She is very blunt and always says what she thinks.
To be blunt, your work is not good enough.

words.meaning: To get on or into (a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle).
examples: The passengers boarded the plane.
He boarded the train just as it was about to leave.

words.meaning: To cause (a vehicle, animal, or person) to become stuck in mud or wet ground.
examples: The car got bogged down in the mud.
Don't get bogged down in the details.

words.meaning: Not genuine or true; fake.
examples: The a bogus ID card.
The claims were completely bogus.

words.meaning: (of a person, event, or behavior) noisy, energetic, and cheerful; rowdy.
examples: The boisterous children were running around the house.
The party was a boisterous affair.

words.meaning: To support or strengthen.
examples: He bolstered his argument with new evidence.
The new policy is intended to bolster the economy.

words.meaning: High-sounding language with little meaning, used to impress people.
examples: The politician's speech was full of bombast and empty promises.
His writing is full of bombast and self-importance.

words.meaning: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.
examples: He delivered a bombastic speech that was full of hot air.
The bombastic language of the advertisement was off-putting.

words.meaning: Genuine; real.
examples: He is a bona fide expert in his field.
She made a bona fide offer to buy the house.

words.meaning: Cheerful friendliness; geniality.
examples: There was a feeling of bonhomie in the room.
He was full of bonhomie and good humor.

words.meaning: A thing that is helpful or beneficial.
examples: The new bridge will be a boon to the local community.
The good weather was a boon to the farmers.

words.meaning: An unrefined, ill-mannered person.
examples: He is a boor who doesn't know how to behave in polite society.
The boor at the next table was talking loudly on his phone.

words.meaning: Rough and bad-mannered; coarse.
examples: His boorish behavior at the party was embarrassing.
The boorish man was asked to leave the restaurant.

words.meaning: (of an action) ineffectual; useless.
examples: His efforts to save the company were bootless.
It was a bootless errand.

words.meaning: Relating to or affecting cattle.
examples: Bovine spongiform encephalopathy is a fatal disease in cattle.
He had a bovine expression on his face.

words.meaning: To wave or flourish (something, especially a weapon) as a threat or in anger or excitement.
examples: He brandished a knife at the terrified cashier.
The protesters brandished banners and chanted slogans.

words.meaning: Self-assertive in a rude, noisy, or overbearing way.
examples: He is a brash and arrogant young man.
The brash new building clashed with the surrounding architecture.

words.meaning: The most important and fundamental aspects of a situation; the essentials.
examples: Let's get down to brass tacks and talk about the budget.
It's time to stop arguing and get down to brass tacks.

words.meaning: A bold manner or a show of boldness intended to impress or intimidate.
examples: His bravado masked his fear.
The robber's bravado quickly disappeared when the police arrived.

words.meaning: Bold and without shame.
examples: He told a brazen lie.
The brazen thief stole the car in broad daylight.

words.meaning: An act of breaking or failing to observe a law, agreement, or code of conduct.
examples: The company was sued for breach of contract.
The security breach exposed the personal data of millions of users.

words.meaning: To do or say something to relieve tension or get conversation going in a strained situation or when strangers meet.
examples: He told a joke to break the ice.
The party games helped to break the ice.
